ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned more about urban anthropology.
I learned about different sociological frameworks, such as Marx and Weber's frameworks, and I also learned about different cultural phenomenons, such as state-planned economies in China.
A pretty broad overview about a variety of Asian cities and their development, in addition to general ideas about urban movements/change.
How to do a literature review, how to write a thesis proposal, what anthropology is

Learn about various sociological and anthropological frameworks to view city and city residents.
Many interesting and meaningful readings.
Developed research and analytical skills.
The Weberian turn in the history of thought in Anthropology. Research method and research design on studying cultural flows, especially in world cities.
I learned how to effectively write a research proposal, and broadened my knowledge of urban anthropology.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very lecture heavy course.
The readings are a strength of the course - they are very engaging and well chosen. I wish we had more time to discuss all of the readings in class!

Strengths: The content was really interesting, the professor is super passionate, and it's overall not too much work. 
Weaknesses: The final paper reallllly sneaks up on you (it's 25 pgs double spaced). The communication was also a little difficult during the course; due dates were only communicated during class, but it wasn't too big an issue. A few of the seminars also weren't all too engaging as it was mostly the professor talking for the whole 110-minute slot.

This was a leminar, meaning Professor Siu spoke for almost all of it. I would have preferred more time for us to engage and discuss, perhaps by having students present on the readings at the beginning of class
The last few weeks could use more in-class discussion on the readings.
I think there could be more discussion in class, although I like the lecture part really well.

I enjoyed the content of this course quite a bit, and found the readings engaging and informative. However, I believe this course could be improved by facilitating more active student engagement in the classroom. Right now, the class dynamic feels very much more like a lecture, and in most class periods, there isn't much opportunity for student discussion or critical analysis of the materials. I think I would have felt more engaged in the classroom if we had had a chance to participate more actively.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Great to learn anthropology with Professor Siu!

Yes! You learn so much about what it means to be human from taking an anthropology class like this. This class is also fascinating because you learn about Asian cultures from a very different lens than is traditionally applied in Western anthropological studies.

Yes, if you are interested and will be able to start the final paper early. As someone with no background in anthropology or east asian studies, I felt out of my depth at times, though that's somewhat expected from a higher-level class. It's very easy to be disengaged if you are otherwise busy, but if you care you will definitely get a lot out of it. Just be really careful about that final paper; it really becomes an issue if you procrastinate.
I would if they were interested in learning a bit about Professor Sius takes on anthropology. However, she does lecture quite a bit and it can get repetitive.
Yes, the class explores the layers of history behind modern world cities, and for anyone interested in East Asian Culture and Urban studies, this class should not be missed.
Yes. This is a great class for people interested in cultural anthropology, especially with non-Eurocentric favor.
Yes, but with the caveat that it feels a lot more like a lecture than a seminar class.
Yes, great course!
